title: Problem Introduction
content: **Erdos Problem #418** asks whether there are infinitely many non-cototients - positive integers that cannot be written as n - phi(n) for any n.
mathContext: The answer is YES, proved by Browkin and Schinzel (1995). The key construction: 2^k * 509203 are non-cototients for all k >= 1.

title: Cototient Function
content: **cototient(n)** = n - phi(n) counts the integers from 1 to n that share a common factor with n. This is the complement of Euler's totient.
mathContext: For n = 6: phi(6) = 2 (only 1 and 5 are coprime to 6), so cototient(6) = 6 - 2 = 4 (the numbers 2, 3, 4, 6 share factors with 6).

title: Cototient Value
content: **IsCototientValue(m)** says m is in the range of the cototient function - there exists some n with cototient(n) = m.
mathContext: For example, 4 is a cototient value because cototient(6) = 4 and cototient(8) = 4.

title: Non-Cototient
content: **IsNonCototient(m)** says m > 0 and m is NOT a cototient value. These are numbers that cannot be expressed as n - phi(n) for any n.
mathContext: The smallest non-cototient is 10. No matter what n you choose, n - phi(n) never equals 10.

title: cototient(1) = 0
content: **cototient_one** shows 1 - phi(1) = 1 - 1 = 0. The only positive integer <= 1 is 1 itself, which is coprime to 1.

title: cototient(2) = 1
content: **cototient_two** shows 2 - phi(2) = 2 - 1 = 1. Only 1 is coprime to 2, so one integer (2 itself) shares a factor.
mathContext: Verified by native_decide which computes phi(2) = 1 directly.

title: cototient(p) = 1 for Prime p
content: **cototient_prime** proves that for any prime p, cototient(p) = 1. Since phi(p) = p - 1, we get p - (p-1) = 1.
mathContext: Uses Nat.totient_prime and omega tactic. The only non-coprime integer in [1,p] is p itself.

title: Small Cototient Values
content: **zero_is_cototient** through **four_is_cototient** verify that 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 are all cototient values with explicit witnesses.

title: 10 is a Non-Cototient
content: **ten_is_non_cototient** states that 10 is the smallest non-cototient. No n satisfies n - phi(n) = 10.
mathContext: Proving this requires exhaustive search or clever analysis. The OEIS sequence A005278 lists non-cototients: 10, 26, 34, 50, ...

title: Browkin-Schinzel Base
content: **browkinSchinzelBase** = 509203 is the magic number from Browkin and Schinzel's 1995 paper. All 2^k * 509203 are non-cototients.
mathContext: The number 509203 has special properties related to covering systems and modular arithmetic that make this construction work.

title: Witness Sequence
content: **browkinSchinzelWitness(k)** = 2^(k+1) * 509203 gives infinitely many non-cototients as k ranges over natural numbers.
mathContext: k=0 gives 1018406, k=1 gives 2036812, k=2 gives 4073624, etc. Each is a non-cototient.

title: Main Theorem (SOLVED)
content: **erdos_418** states NonCototients.Infinite - there are infinitely many non-cototients. This answers Erdos's question affirmatively.
mathContext: The proof uses the Browkin-Schinzel witness sequence, which provides infinitely many distinct non-cototients.

title: Strengthened Goldbach
content: **StrengthenedGoldbach** requires every even n > 6 to be a sum of two DISTINCT primes. This is slightly stronger than standard Goldbach.
mathContext: Standard Goldbach allows p + p (same prime twice). The strengthened version needs p + q with p != q.

title: Odd Numbers are Cototients
content: **odd_cototient_conditional** shows that under strengthened Goldbach, every odd m is a cototient value.
mathContext: For odd m >= 7: m+1 is even > 6, so m+1 = p+q (distinct primes). Then cototient(p*q) = p*q - (p-1)(q-1) = p+q-1 = m.

title: Small Odd Cases
content: **small_odd_cototients** verifies 1, 3, 5 are cototients directly: 1 = cototient(2), 3 = cototient(9), 5 = cototient(25).
mathContext: These handle the base cases (m < 7) separately from the Goldbach-based argument.

title: Density Question (OPEN)
content: **density_open** marks the open question: do non-cototients have positive density? The Browkin-Schinzel set has density 0.
mathContext: Positive density would mean a constant fraction of integers are non-cototients. The exponentially sparse witness set doesn't prove this.

title: Nonaliquots Have Positive Density
content: **erdos_nonaliquot_density** states that numbers not of the form sigma(n) - n (nonaliquots) have positive density. Erdos proved this in 1973.
mathContext: This contrasts with non-cototients where density is unknown. Banks-Luca showed density >= 1/48; Chen-Zhao improved to 0.06.

title: Summary
content: **erdos_418_summary** packages key facts: the base 509203, and the first two witnesses 2*509203 and 4*509203.
mathContext: Verified computationally using native_decide to check the arithmetic.
